{{unreferenced|date=January 2011}} {{use dmy dates|date=July 2012}} {{Infobox organization | name = National Committee on American Foreign Policy | image = NCAFP Logo-96x94pixels-12.9KB-JPEG.jpg | alt = | caption = | map = | msize = | malt = | mcaption = | map2 = | abbreviation = NCAFP | motto = | formation = 1974 (by [[Hans Morgenthau]]) | type = Non-profit, nonpartisan activist organization | status = | purpose = | headquarters = 320 [[Park Avenue]]
[[New York City]], [[New York (state)|New York]]
United States | coords = | region_served = | membership = | language = | general = | leader_title = Acting President | leader_name = Jeffrey R. Shafer | leader_title2 = | leader_name2 = | leader_title3 = | leader_name3 = | leader_title4 = | leader_name4 = | key_people = | main_organ = | affiliations = | budget = | num_staff = | num_volunteers = | website = [http://www.ncafp.org www.ncafp.org] }} The '''National Committee on American Foreign Policy''' ('''NCAFP''') is an American nonprofit, nonpartisan activist organization dedicated to the resolution of conflicts that threaten United States interests. Founded in 1974 by [[Hans Morgenthau]], the organization works to identify, articulate, and advance [[foreign policy of the United States|U.S. foreign-policy]] interests within the framework of political realism. ==Mission== The U.S. foreign-policy interests of the NCAFP include: * Preserving and strengthening [[national security]] * Supporting countries committed to the values and practice of political, religious, and cultural [[Pluralism (political philosophy)|pluralism]] * Improving U.S. relations with the developed and developing worlds * Advancing [[human rights]] * Encouraging realist [[arms control|arms-control]] agreements * Curbing the proliferation of [[nuclear weapons|nuclear]] and other [[unconventional warfare|unconventional weapons]] * Promoting an open and global economy The organization believes that an informed public is vital to a democratic society. To promote this, it offers educational programs to its members and general audiences that address security challenges facing the U.S. and publishes a variety of publications, including the bimonthly journal, ''American Foreign Policy Interests''. ==History== The National Committee was founded in 1974 by Hans J. Morgenthau and others dedicated to the resolution of conflicts that threaten U.S. interests. The National Committee grew quickly in size and influence. It held public seminars regularly, assembled task forces in order to analyze areas of critical concern to the United States, and published journals and pamphlets containing summaries and policy recommendations derived from high-level conferences and briefings featuring American and foreign policymakers. In 1981, the first Hans J. Morgenthau Award was presented to NCAFP president [[Angier Biddle Duke]]. Subsequent recipients have included [[Henry Kissinger]], [[George Shultz]], [[James Baker III]], the [[Margaret Thatcher]], and [[Colin Powell]]. A second award, the George F. Kennan Award for Distinguished Public Service, was established in 1994. Recipients include [[George F. Kennan]], the [[Cyrus R. Vance]], the [[Paul A. Volcker]], [[Richard C. Holbrooke]], [[John D. Negroponte]], and General [[David H. Petraeus]]. In 1993 William J. Flynn, chairman and chief executive officer of [[Mutual of America]], became the chairman of the National Committee. When the British and Irish governments issued the [[Downing Street Declaration]] at the end of that year, the National Committee under his leadership placed a full-page ad in ''[[The New York Times]]'' challenging every party involved in the conflict to attend an NCAFP-sponsored conference to air the arguments of all sides. The National Committee was instrumental in convincing President [[Bill Clinton]] to issue a visa to [[Gerry Adams]], the leader of [[Sinn Féin]]. Adams's first appearance in the United States enabled him to begin to develop ties with key leaders in New York and Washington that gave him and his party the assurance necessary to enter into peace negotiations, sign the [[Belfast Agreement]], and contend for and win political office in the North. In recognition of William Flynn's achievements, the National Committee established the William J. Flynn Initiative for Peace Award in 1997. Among the recipients are [[George J. Mitchell]], [[Marjorie Mowlam]], [[Viola Drath]], [[Hugh Carey]], and Gerry Adams, M.P. Shortly after establishing its Northern Ireland project, the NCAFP launched its [[Track II diplomacy|track I-½ and track II project]] on [[U.S.-China relations]] and the question of [[Taiwan]]. The project gradually grew into the Forum on Asia-Pacific Security. The NCAFP, under this thematic umbrella, sponsored security talks with North Korea on nuclear issues and, more recently, security issues affecting [[Japan–United States relations|U.S.-Japan]] and [[South Korea–United States relations|U.S.-South Korea]] relations. The entire Forum on Asia-Pacific Security is largely conducted at track I-½ and track II levels. Since its founding, the National Committee has focused its attention on significant geopolitical regions such as the [[Middle East]] and strategic partnerships such as [[Transatlantic relations|Transatlantic Relations]]. More recently, as an outgrowth of those studies, the NCAFP established projects on the [[Caspian Sea|Caspian Sea Basin]] and [[United States and the United Nations|U.S.-UN relations]], as well as on [[Africa]]. While the Committee's scope has broadened, it remains anchored to its values: the preservation and strengthening of national security; supporting political, religious, and cultural pluralism; improving U.S. relations with its allies; advancing [[human rights]]; curbing nuclear proliferation and encouraging realistic arms-control agreements; and promoting an open global economy. ==Task forces== Its long-term task forces bring together U.S. and foreign scholars, foreign-policy practitioners, and others to off-the-record and sometimes closed-door forums where adversaries can, over a period of years, air their views unencumbered by official rhetoric. Shorter-term task forces deal with immediate foreign policy challenges facing the U.S. ===Meetings=== The organization's Meetings Program offers members and guests the opportunity to share their thoughts on U.S. foreign policy with influential policymakers, diplomats, renowned scholars, and foreign policy specialists. Each year, the organization convenes a series of programs, including single speaker events, panels and round tables addressing immediate and long-term issues of national security. ===Special initiatives=== In May 2004, it launched its Forum on Northeast Asian Security. Projects chaired by [[Henry Kissinger]] and [[Paul Volcker]] include exploring the potential for a nuclear-free [[Korean Peninsula]]; a Northeast Asian Security Forum, composed of the U.S., [[Japan]], [[China]], [[Russia]], [[South Korea]] and [[North Korea]]; and breaking the impasse between [[China]] and [[Taiwan]]. ==Publications== A distinguishing activity of the organization is the publication and dissemination of firm, reasoned positions designed to help formulate American foreign policy. When, after study and discussion, the organization or one of its task forces reaches a consensus on an aspect of foreign policy that affects American national interests, it makes that judgment known to the Administration, the [[United States Congress|U.S. Congress]], the media and the general public. ===''American Foreign Policy Interests''=== A long-time component of the organization's publication series was its bimonthly journal, ''American Foreign Policy Interests''. The journal presented authoritative and provocative articles on critical questions of foreign policy written by leading scholars and policy experts. It was discontinued in 2015. ===Books and booklets=== The organization publishes short booklets of policy reports and recommendations. Additionally, the organization publishes speeches and summaries of discussions that have been the hallmarks of its foreign policy briefings, lecture series, and award ceremonies. ==Awards== The organization presents five awards: ===Hans J. Morgenthau Award=== The award was established in 1981 to commemorate Morgenthau's seminal contributions to the theory and the practice of American foreign policy. It is awarded to an individual whose intellectual attainments and/or practical contributions to U.S. foreign policy have been judged so exemplary in the tradition of Professor Morgenthau as to merit this singular award. Recipients include:{{clarify|date=July 2012|reason=unordered list. didn't alpha because it might be chrono, it which case years need to be added.}} {{div col|colwidth=30em}} * [[Angier Biddle Duke]] * [[Sol Linowitz]] * [[Henry Kissinger]] * [[Jeane Kirkpatrick]] * [[George P. Shultz]] * [[David Rockefeller]] * [[James Baker]] * [[Margaret Thatcher]] * [[Thomas R. Pickering]] * King [[Hussein of Jordan]] * [[Colin Powell]] * [[Richard N. Haass]] {{div col end}} ===George F. Kennan Award for Distinguished Public Service=== The award was established in 1994 in honor of [[George F. Kennan]], scholar, diplomat and statesman. It honors an American who has served the U.S. in an exemplary way and has made a seminal contribution to defining and illuminating the national interests of the U.S. Recipients include:{{clarify|date=July 2012|reason=unordered list. didn't alpha because it might be chrono, it which case years need to be added.}} {{div col|colwidth=30em}} * [[George F. Kennan]] * [[Cyrus Vance]] * [[Paul Volcker]] * [[Richard Holbrooke]] * [[Maurice R. Greenberg]] * [[John Negroponte]] * General [[David Petraeus]] * [[Raymond Kelly]] {{div col end}} ===William J. Flynn Initiative for Peace Award=== The award was established 1997 as the Initiative for Peace Award in honor of [[William J. Flynn (NCAFP)|William J. Flynn]], NCAFP chairman, for his decisive leadership and daring diplomacy in spurring two cease-fires and promoting the peace process in [[Northern Ireland]]. Renamed in 2001, it is presented to an individual who has worked tirelessly to resolve a conflict that has affected the national interests of the U.S. Recipients include:{{clarify|date=July 2012|reason=unordered list. didn't alpha because it might be chrono, it which case years need to be added.}} {{div col|colwidth=30em}} * [[William J. Flynn (NCAFP)|William J. Flynn]] * [[George J. Mitchell]] * [[Marjorie Mowlam]] * [[Viola Herms Drath]] * [[Hugh Carey]] * [[Gerry Adams]] {{div col end}} ===Global Business Leadership Award=== The award honors a prominent business leader whose efforts have contributed to setting an unimpeachable standard for globally oriented corporate citizenship promoting the national interests of the U.S.{{clarify|date=July 2012|reason=when established?}} Recipients include: * [[Paul E. Jacobs]] ===21st Century Leader Award=== The award was created{{when|date=July 2012}} to recognize the achievements of individuals under the age of 40 who display a serious commitment to furthering the U.S.'s strategic policy interests in accord with the principles of political realism. Through their professional or personal pursuits, they make important contributions to the international dialogue and demonstrate a promising future in the realm of U.S. foreign policy. Recipients include:{{clarify|date=July 2012|reason=unordered list. didn't alpha because it might be chrono, it which case years need to be added.}} {{div col|colwidth=30em}} * [[Nancy Walbridge Collins]] * Abraham Denmark * Marisa Porges * [[Nathaniel Fick]] * [[John Delury]] * [[Joshua Cooper Ramo]] * Nicholas Thompson {{div col end}} ==See also== {{portal|Government of the United States|Politics}} * [[List of think tanks in the United States]] {{clear}} ==External links== * {{official website|http://www.ncafp.org}} {{coord|40.75745|-73.97414|type:landmark_globe:earth_region:US-NY|display=title}} [[Category:1974 establishments in New York (state)]] [[Category:Foreign policy and strategy think tanks in the United States]] [[Category:Organizations based in Manhattan]] [[Category:Non-profit organizations based in New York City]] [[Category:Realist think tanks]] [[Category:Think tanks established in 1974]]

{{Multiple issues| {{Unreliable sources|date=January 2011}} {{Editorial|date=January 2011}} }} {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2011}} '''Noah Musingku''', under the name "King David Peii II", is head of the twin "kingdoms" of [[Papaala]] and [[Me’ekamui]] on [[Bougainville Island]] in the [[North Solomon Islands]]. Musingku is the creator of [[U-Vistract]] which was banned as a [[pyramid scheme]] outside of the kingdoms.[http://www.abc.net.au/worldtoday/content/2005/s1507281.htm "Mercenaries return to PNG"], ''The World Today/ABC Radio'', 15 November 2005[http://www.islandsbusiness.com/news/index_dynamic/containerNameToReplace=MiddleMiddle/focusModuleID=130/focusContentID=7084/tableName=mediaRelease/overideSkinName=newsArticle-full.tpl "Musingku urged to surrender"], ''Post-Courier'', 30 November 2006[http://www.fijitimes.com/story.aspx?id=81131 "Fijians look forward to re-uniting with families"] ''Fiji Times Online'', 12 February 2008[http://www.postcourier.com.pg/20060913/bville.htm "SI border raids prompt talks"], ''Papua New Guinea Post-Courier'', 13 September 2006Ilya Gridneff, [http://news.smh.com.au/breaking-news-world/uvistract-conman-offers-jesus-money-20090708-dcuu.html "U-Vistract conman offers 'Jesus money'"], ''Sydney Morning Herald'', 8 July 2009 ==Background== [[File:Tonu village in southeast Siwai, Bougainville, 1977.jpg|left|thumb|250px|Tonu, Noah Musingku's native village in southeast Siwai, Bougainville.]]Bougainville Island is geographically and ethnically a part of the [[Solomon Island]] archipelago. It was an autonomous region of [[Papua New Guinea]] (PNG). In 1988 a civil war began with workers and landowners from [[Panguna mine]] (See also [[Panguna]]). This mine, owned by the PNG government and [[Bougainville Copper]], a subsidiary of [[Rio Tinto Group]], was established under Australian aegis.The Times, 4 September 1975 A Unilateral Declaration of Independence was made on 17 May 1990, but Australian and New Zealand-brokered peace talks tended to ignore this fact. [[Francis Ona]] controlled over half of the island, and proclaimed himself king of Me’ekamui (“holy land”) in May 2004. Musingku assumed the throne of Paapala Kingdom, as well as his 500-man "Me'ekamui Defense Force"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xYsDWautKpc in the same year, and upon Ona’s death from malaria in July 2005, Musingku consolidated control of the “Twin Kingdoms” on Bougainville Island. ==U-Vistract== {{main|U-Vistract}} In 1997, seven years after the unilateral declaration of independence, the Bougainville Revolutionary Army was in control of the island, but its leadership split into factions. Ona was in control of the army, and sought full independence. His co-president in the [[Bougainville Interim Government]], [[Joseph Kabui]], sought rapprochement with PNG and formation of an [[Autonomous Bougainville Government]]. Musingku met with each of them as a mediator, and by 19 December 1997 had signed agreements with each. They jointly realized that it would be impossible to achieve political independence without financial sovereignty.{{cite web |url=http://www.ibom.biz/public%20docos/Issue%207.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-01-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110706151616/http://www.ibom.biz/public%20docos/Issue%207.pdf |archivedate=6 July 2011 |df=dmy-all }} Papala Chronicles Issue 7 p 10 As Musingku’s wrote, :''In other words, Bougainville needed to create her own independent and sovereign system in order to be free from the control of the other international financial and governing structure. Also, it was very clear that the funds we needed to work with in uprooting, pulling down, destroying and overthrowing the existing foreign control system could not be earned through the conventional system. A new international system needed to be established whose control and coordination would not be based overseas but right here on our own soil.'' At first, the “U-Vistract Mission” was established as a Christian mission program in Australia. [[Australian Securities and Investments Commission]] (ASIC) found it to be an unlicensed securities and investment program. :''Within a few years, some 70,000 Papua New Guineans had deposited K350 million into U-Vistract alone. U-Vistract also attracted followers in Australia, Solomon Islands and Fiji. In Australia, a small number of Queensland investors contributed some AUD500,000 between July and October 1999.''[http://www.csrm.uq.edu.au/docs/SSGM_09_05_bainton_cox.pdf] http://www.csrm.uq.edu.au/docs/SSGM_09_05_bainton_cox.pdf
"On October 19th 1999 in one of my trips to Australia the ASIC placed me under house-arrest…. After a heavy interrogatory session they demanded me to shut down all my operations in the country. The ASIC publicized the matter in the media to let the world of Australia know about the so-called illegal operations. However, U-Vistract grew even stronger, gaining momentum almost overnight. The number of my agencies grew in Kempsey, Sydney, Brisbane, Gold coast, etc."{{cite web |url=http://www.ibom.biz/public%20docos/Issue%205.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-01-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110706151721/http://www.ibom.biz/public%20docos/Issue%205.pdf |archivedate=6 July 2011 |df=dmy-all }} Papala Chronicles Issue 5 p 9
From Australia, he went to Pt Moresby, Papua New Guinea. While in Pt Moresby, he tried to set up a bank in the old Hawaiian Bank building, but he was shut down by the PNG government and forced to leave to the Solomon Islands. He began again to set up his system, but the Australian police in the [[Regional Assistance Mission to Solomon Islands]] (RAMSI) forced him out. In 2003 he travelled to Ona’s headquarters in Guava, Panguna, Bougainville, and established a bank there. Two years later he was able to travel to his ancestral village of Tonu, where he established his bank headquarters in an old cattle farm owned by the paramount chief.{{citation needed|date=December 2012}} ==Beliefs== A [[Pentecostal]] Christian, most of his talks and writings are generously sprinkled with biblical references. U-Vistract was initially created as a Christian Mission, and this has continued to be its focus.{{citation needed|date=December 2012}} Musingku has compared his life and mission to that of Biblical saviors Noah, Moses or Jesus Christ. On the new currency that he intends to issue, pictures of Jesus will join the likenesses of Musingku and other Bougainvillean leaders. ==Fijian Soldiers Incident== {{Main|Fijian_mercenaries_in_Bougainville}} Musingku exercised his powers as Head of State of Bougainville. In 2005 he announced that he was hiring a security force from [[Fiji]] to train his guards and other governmental personnel, as well as establish security and satellite and other telecommunications for his bank in Tonu.[http://www.ibom.biz/public%20docos/Issue%2018.pdf] Papala Chronicles Issue 18[http://www.ibom.biz/public%20docos/Issue%2019.pdf] Papala Chronicles Issue 19 He said that this Fijian security force had been hand selected "mostly [[born again (Christianity)|Born-Again Christians]] with overseas experience in Iraq and other areas". ==References== {{Reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Musingku, Noah}} [[Category:Papua New Guinean politicians]] [[Category:Separatism in Papua New Guinea]] [[Category:Rebels]] [[Category:People from the Autonomous Region of Bougainville]] [[Category:Heads of state of unrecognized or largely unrecognized states]] [[Category:Oceanian monarchs]] [[Category:Oceanian kings]]

{{Infobox Government agency |agency_name = Norwegian Universities and Colleges Admission Service |nativename = Samordna opptak |nativename_a = |nativename_r = |logo = Samordna opptak.png |logo_width = |logo_caption = |seal = |seal_width = |seal_caption = |formed = 1991 |preceding1 = |preceding2 = |dissolved = |superseding = |jurisdiction = [[Government of Norway]] |headquarters = [[Oslo]] |employees = 26 centrally + 10 hired IT-staff |budget = Ca 21.000.000 NOK |minister1_name = |minister1_pfo = |minister2_name = |minister2_pfo = |chief1_name = Bente Ringlund |chief1_position = Daglig leder |chief2_name = |chief2_position = |parent_agency = |child1_agency = |child2_agency = |website = [http://info.samordnaopptak.no/ www.samordnaopptak.no] |footnotes = }}
The '''Norwegian Universities and Colleges Admission Service''' ({{lang-no|Samordna opptak}}) is a [[Norway|Norwegian]] [[etat|government agency]] responsible for application and admission to all public [[university|universities]] and [[university college]]s in Norway for entry level degrees, either [[Bachelor degree]]s for liberal studies and some professional studies, as well as certain [[Master degree|Master]] level programs in professional studies. The agency is subordinate to the [[Norwegian Ministry of Education and Research]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.regjeringen.no/nb/dep/kd/dep/Underliggende-etater/Samordna-opptak.html?id=426565 |title=Samordna opptak |author=[[Norwegian Ministry of Education and Research]] |accessdate=2008-04-30}}</ref> and is managed by the [[University of Oslo]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.usit.uio.no/suaf/so/Historie/suaf_historie.html |title=Gruppe for Samordna opptak (SUAF-SO) |author=[[University of Oslo]] |accessdate=2008-04-30 |language=Norwegian}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref>
==History== Traditionally Norwegian universities and colleges had a system of local admission control. This system was tedious since each person had to apply to each institution and it was difficult to manage declines from students who were accepted to other institutions. Particularly in 1990 there was a massive increase in the application to higher educations and this resulted in an immense workload on the local administrators.
To solve this problem, the Government initiated a program to effectivise the application and admission system. Until 1994 the system merely collected information from the institutions, but from 1995 for the colleges and 1997 for the universities the admission rankings were centralized through the system so each applicant only got one admission place. From 1999 application via the Internet was possible, and from 2008 only online application is possible. After 2000 the grades from the upper secondary schools are automatically transferred to the system.
==How it works== The system opens on February 1 each year, with application deadline April 15. Some special groups have application deadline March 1. On the application up to ten prioritized programs can be specified. The order of their programs can be altered up to July 1, but no new program can be added after April 15. On July 20 the main admission is run and made known to the applicants, and no one is given more than one admission; on the highest ranked program that the candidate is qualified for and has enough points for after a specialized [[stable marriage]] algorithm. Programs with more applicants get [[Wait list|waiting list]]s. Later in the summer and during the fall more people are admitted from the lists if enough people from the main admission decline the places. Studies with insufficient applicants to fill up become part of the ''Remains Market'' (Restetorget), which offers first-to-grab principle after the main application. Only entry-level programs are run through the system. Admission from bachelor to master level programs is still handled locally.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://info.samordnaopptak.no/english |title=English |author=Norwegian Universities and Colleges Admission Service |accessdate=2008-04-30 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080421165617/http://info.samordnaopptak.no/english |archive-date=2008-04-21 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref>
The applicants is ranked on a point scheme, where the qualified candidates with the most points are given admission. The qualifications vary from program to program, but almost all require general university admissions certification. Some programs, like engineering or medicine require extra upper secondary level courses in [[mathematics]] and [[sciences]], which can be attained through a foundation course in engineering. The points are based first on the average grade from upper secondary school, multiplied by ten. Additional points are awarded for sciences, age, specialization and completed 60 [[European Credit Transfer and Accumulation System|ECTS]] credits or [[military service]]. Quota points for gender are applicable for some programs.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.lovdata.no/for/sf/kd/kd-20051010-1191.html |title=Forskrift om opptak til universiteter og høyskoler. |author=Norwegian Ministry of Education and Research |date=2006-01-01 |language=Norwegian}}</ref>
The institution who owns the top prioritized program on each application is defined as the case handler for that application. The case handler sets the correct points values and (dis)qualification codes. Often helped by the national database for upper secondary school diplomas, also run by Samordna opptak. Each applicant has in average 1.1 case handlers compared to one per institution before 1995.
==Numbers== In 2007 92,750 people applied for studying through the system, of which 76,936 sent in necessary documentation and 69,529 were qualified. Two of three people who were offered a place through the main admission, were granted their first choice. There are about 1,200 possible programs at seven universities and about 40 colleges.

{{Infobox publisher | image = [[File:OR Books logo (transparent).png]] | parent = | status = | founded = 2009 | founder = John Oakes and Colin Robinson | successor = | country = [[United States]] | headquarters = [[New York City, New York]] | distribution = [[Counterpoint (publisher)|Counterpoint]]<ref>{{Cite web| title = For Booksellers| work = OR Books| accessdate = 2018-01-06| url = http://www.orbooks.com/booksellers/}}</ref> | keypeople = | publications = [[Books]] | topics = | genre = | imprints = | revenue = | numemployees = | nasdaq = | url = {{URL|https://www.orbooks.com/}} }} '''OR Books''' is a New York-based independent publishing house founded by John Oakes and Colin Robinson in 2009.<ref>[http://www.crainsnewyork.com/article/20090712/SMALLBIZ/307129981.html: Crain's New York Business on the founding of OR Books]</ref> The company sells digital and [[Print on demand|print-on-demand]] books directly to the customer and focuses on creative promotion through traditional media and the Internet.<ref>[http://paw.princeton.edu/issues/2011/03/02/pages/6852/ "Oakes ’83 connects readers directly to a publisher"], ''Princeton Alumni Weekly'', March 2, 2011.</ref> On its site, OR Books states that it "embraces progressive change in politics, culture and the way we do business."
Not long after its founding in 2009, OR Books became known for publishing ''[[Going Rouge: Sarah Palin, An American Nightmare]]'', a parody of the [[Sarah Palin]] biography, which went on to become a ''[[New York Times]]'' Best Seller. Since then the company has published books by [[Julian Assange]], [[Moustafa Bayoumi]], [[Medea Benjamin]], [[Patrick Cockburn]], [[Sue Coe]], [[Simon Critchley]], Lisa Dierbeck, [[Ariel Dorfman]], [[Norman Finkelstein]], [[Laura Flanders]], Chris Lehmann, [[Gordon Lish]], [[Bill McKibben]], [[Eileen Myles]], [[Yoko Ono]], [[Barney Rosset]], [[Douglas Rushkoff]], [[Elissa Shevinsky]], [[Burhan Sönmez]], [[Jeanne Thornton]], and others.
==Founders== According to OR's website, John Oakes co-founded the publishing company [[Four Walls Eight Windows]] and was subsequently publisher of [[Thunder's Mouth Press]] and co-publisher of [[Nation Books]]. He is publisher of the [[Evergreen Review]]. Colin Robinson, a former senior editor at [[Charles Scribner's Sons|Scribner]], was previously managing director of [[Verso Books]] and publisher of [[The New Press]].
==Joint ventures== In September 2010, OR Books announced a partnership with a writers' collective known as Mischief & Mayhem, whose members include [[Dale Peck]], Lisa Dierbeck, [[Joshua Furst]], [[DW Gibson]], and [[Choire Sicha]].<ref>Leon Neyfakh, [http://observer.com/2010/09/dale-peck-choire-sicha-and-friends-start-a-book-publishing-collective-first-title-out-next-month/ "Dale Peck, Choire Sicha and Friends Start a Book Publishing Collective; First Title Out Next Month"], ''[[New York Observer]]'', September 10, 2010.</ref>
In what the industry newsblog [[Shelf Awareness]] termed a "very significant...move," [[St. Mark’s Bookshop]] and OR Books announced a joint venture to enable the store’s customers to buy select books on OR’s list from the bookstore’s website.<ref>[http://www.shelf-awareness.com/issue.html?issue=1345.html "St. Mark's/OR Alliance"], Shelf Awareness.</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Teicher| first=Craig Morgan| title=OR Books Partners with St. Mark's Bookshop for E-Book Distribution |date =December 7, 2010| work=Publishers Weekly |url=http://www.publishersweekly.com/pw/by-topic/digital/retailing/article/45428-or-books-partners-with-st-mark-s-bookshop-for-e-book-distribution.html | accessdate = July 14, 2014}}</ref>
In April 2016, OR Books acquired UK publishing company [[Serif (publisher)|Serif]], following the death in 2015 of its founder Stephen Hayward, a former associate of Robinson's.<ref>[http://www.bookbusinessmag.com/article/press-release-new-york-based-or-books-acquires-serif-books/ "Press Release: New York-Based OR Books Acquires Serif Books"], ''BookBusiness'', April 11, 2016.</ref><ref>[http://www.orbooks.com/ "Welcome to OR Books".]</ref><ref>Calvin Reid, [http://www.publishersweekly.com/pw/by-topic/industry-news/publisher-news/article/69958-or-books-acquires-u-k-s-serif-books.html "OR Books Acquires U.K.'s Serif Books"], ''[[Publishers Weekly]]'', April 14, 2016.</ref><ref>[http://www.shelf-awareness.com/issue.html?issue=2733#m32128 "OR Books Acquires Serif Books"], ''Shelf Awareness'', April 15, 2016.</ref>
In May 2016, OR Books and [[Counterpoint Press]] announced a partnership whereby Counterpoint would put a number of OR's titles into stores. <ref>[http://www.publishersweekly.com/pw/by-topic/industry-news/publisher-news/article/70200-counterpoint-press-partners-with-or-books.html "Counterpoint, OR Books Partner on New Fall List"], Publishers Weekly, May 5, 2016.</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
==External links== * [https://www.orbooks.com/ Company site] * [https://www.facebook.com/orbooks/ OR Books] on Facebook. * John Oakes, [http://www.publishersweekly.com/pw/by-topic/columns-and-blogs/soapbox/article/52000-disintermediating-amazon.html "Disintermediating Amazon"], ''Publishers Weekly'', May 18, 2012. * Colin Robinson, [https://www.nytimes.com/2014/01/05/opinion/sunday/the-loneliness-of-the-long-distance-reader.html?_r=0 "The Loneliness of the Long-Distance Reader"], ''The New York Times'', January 4, 2014. * [http://www.mischiefandmayhembooks.com/ Mischief + Mayhem] * Kat Meyer, [http://radar.oreilly.com/2010/08/toc-evolvers-or-books.html#more/ "TOC Evolvers: OR Books"], August 7, 2010. Interview with John Oakes on O'Reilly Media's TOC (Tools of Change for Publishing). * [http://www.publishersweekly.com/pw/by-topic/industry-news/publisher-news/article/45643-what-s-ahead-in-2011.html ''Publishers Weekly'' discusses OR Books in its 2010 roundup], January 3, 2011. * Jim Barnes, [http://www.independentpublisher.com/article.php?page=1375 "Indie Groundbreaking Publisher: OR Books — A Brave New Publishing Model"], ''Independent Publisher'' article about the success of ''Going Rouge''. * [http://onthemedia.org/transcripts/2009/11/27/01// Interview with Colin Robinson on NPR's On the Media] * Chad W. Post, [http://publishingperspectives.com/2010/10/from-frankfurt-or-books-preaches-elegant-direct-model/ "OR Books Preaches Elegant Direct Model"], ''Publishing Perspectives'', October 6, 2010. * [http://www.nola.com/nolavie/index.ssf/2011/11/words_and_music_fest_features.html "Words & Music Festival 2011 featured fireworks, and a little sadness"], Nola.com, November 15, 2011 (showdown between OR co-publisher John Oakes and Random House editor). * Dennis Sweeney, [http://entropymag.org/or-books/ "Interview with Colin Robinson, Co-Founder, OR Books"], ''Entropy Magazine'', January 2014.

{{about|political philosophy of Ordoliberalism|their economic system|Freiburg School|the practical implementation in Germany|Social market economy}} {{Liberalism sidebar |Variants}}
'''Ordoliberalism''' is the [[Germany|German]] variant of [[social liberalism]] that emphasizes the need for the state to ensure that the [[free market]] produces results close to its theoretical potential.<ref>{{cite book |first=Ralf |last=Ptak |chapter=Neoliberalism in Germany: Revisiting the Ordoliberal Foundations of the Social Market Economy |editor1-first=Philip |editor1-last=Mirowski |editor2-first=Dieter |editor2-last=Plehwe |title=The Road From Mont Pèlerin: The Making of The Neoliberal Thought Collective |location=Cambridge, MA. |publisher=Harvard University Press |year=2009 |isbn=978-0-674-03318-4 |pages=124–25}}</ref>
Ordoliberal ideals became the foundation of the creation of the post-[[World War II]] German [[social market economy]] and its attendant {{lang|de|[[Wirtschaftswunder]]}}.
The term "ordoliberalism" ({{lang-de|Ordoliberalismus}}) was coined in 1950 by {{lang|de|[[Hero Moeller]]|italic=no}}, and refers to the academic journal ''[[ORDO (journal)|ORDO]]''.<ref>{{cite book |first=Ralf |last=Ptak |title=Vom Ordoliberalismus zur Sozialen Marktwirtschaft: Stationen des Neoliberalismus in Deutschland |publisher=VS Verlag |year=2004 |isbn=978-3-8100-4111-1 |page=23 |language=German}}</ref>
==Linguistic differentiation==
Ordoliberals separate themselves from [[classical liberals]]. Notably {{lang|de|[[Walter Eucken]]|italic=no}}, with {{lang|de|[[Franz Böhm]]|italic=no}}, founder of ordoliberalism and the [[Freiburg School]],<ref name="Goldschmidt2005">{{cite book |author=Nils Goldschmidt |title=Wirtschaft, Politik und Freiheit: Freiburger Wirtschaftswissenschaftler und der Widerstand |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=SvNEWSk_HFQC |accessdate=21 July 2013 |year=2005 |publisher=Mohr Siebeck |isbn=978-3-16-148520-6 |page=315 }}</ref> rejected [[neoliberalism]].<ref name="Gerken2000">{{cite book |author=Lüder Gerken |title=Walter Eucken und sein Werk: Rückblick auf den Vordenker der sozialen Marktwirtschaft |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xx8lxh7PZKMC |accessdate=21 July 2013 |year=2000 |publisher=Mohr Siebeck |isbn=978-3-16-147503-0 |page=37 }}</ref>
Ordoliberals promoted the concept of the social market economy, and this concept promotes a strong role for the state with respect to the market, which is in many ways different from the ideas connected to the term neoliberalism. Oddly the term neoliberalism was originally coined in 1938, at the {{lang|fr|[[Colloque Walter Lippmann]]}}, by {{lang|de|[[Alexander Rüstow]]|italic=no}}, who is regarded an ordoliberal today.<ref name="ReferenceA">{{cite journal |first1=Taylor C. |last1=Boas |first2=Jordan |last2=Gans-Morse |title=Neoliberalism: From New Liberal Philosophy to Anti-Liberal Slogan |journal=Studies in Comparative International Development |volume=44 |issue=2 |year=2009 |issn=0039-3606 |pages=137–61 |doi=10.1007/s12116-009-9040-5}}</ref>
Because of the connected history ordoliberalism is also sometimes referred to as "German neoliberalism". This led to frequent confusion and "mix ups" of terms and ideas in the discourse, debate and criticism of both economic schools of liberalism until in 1991 the political economists {{lang|fr|[[Michel Albert]]|italic=no}} with {{lang|fr|[[Capitalisme Contre Capitalisme]]|italic=yes}} and in 2001 Peter A. Hall and [[David Soskice]] with ''[[Varieties of Capitalism]]'' aimed to separate the concepts and develop the new terms [[liberal market economy]] and [[coordinated market economy]] to distinguish neoliberalism and ordoliberalism.
==Development== The theory was developed from about 1930 to 1950 by [[Germany|German]] [[economists]] and legal scholars from the [[Freiburg School]], such as {{lang|de|Walter Eucken|italic=no}}, {{lang|de|[[Franz Böhm]]|italic=no}}, {{lang|de|[[Hans Grossmann-Doerth]]|italic=no}}, and {{lang|de|[[Leonhard Miksch]]|italic=no}}.
Ordoliberal ideals (with modifications) drove the creation of the post-[[World War II]] German social market economy. They were especially influential on forming a firm [[competition law]] in Germany. However the social market economy was implemented in economies where [[corporatism]] was already well established, so ordoliberal ideals were not as far reaching as the theory's economic founders had intended.<ref name="Abelshauser2005">{{cite book |last1=Abelshauser |first1=Werner |title=The Dynamics of German Industry: Germany's Path toward the New Economy and the American Challenge |date=2005 |publisher=Berghahn Books |isbn=9781782387992 |pages=146-148 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=hkbkBgAAQBAJ |accessdate=9 October 2018 |language=en}}</ref>
Since the 1960s, ordoliberal influence on economics and jurisprudence has significantly diminished<ref>[[Springer Gabler|Gabler Verlag]] (ed.), Gabler Wirtschaftslexikon, Stichwort: Freiburger Schule ([http://wirtschaftslexikon.gabler.de/Archiv/7246/freiburger-schule-v8.html online])</ref> however many German economists define themselves as Ordoliberals through the present day, the ''[[ORDO (journal)|ORDO]]'' is still published, and the Faculty of Economics at the [[University of Freiburg]] is still teaching ordoliberalism. Additionally, some institutes and foundations such as the {{lang|de|[[Walter Eucken Institut]]|italic=no}} and the {{lang|de|[[Stiftung Ordnungspolitik]]|italic=no}} are engaged in the ordoliberal tradition.
==Implementation== [[File:Bundesarchiv B 145 Bild-F004214-0033, Konrad Adenauer und Ludwig Erhard.jpg|thumbnail|{{lang|de|[[Ludwig Erhard]]|italic=no}} with {{lang|de|[[Konrad Adenauer]]|italic=no}} in 1956, while Erhard was Minister of Economics.]] Ordoliberalism was a major influence on the economic model developed in post-war [[West Germany]]. Ordoliberalism in [[Germany]] became known as the social market economy.
The Ordoliberal model implemented in Germany was started under the government administration of {{lang|de|[[Konrad Adenauer]]|italic=no}}. His government's [[Federal Ministry for Economic Affairs and Energy|Minister of Economics]], {{lang|de|[[Ludwig Erhard]]|italic=no}}, was a known Ordoliberal and adherent of the [[Freiburg School]]. Under {{lang|de|Adenauer|italic=no}}, some, but not all, price controls were lifted, and taxes on small businesses and corporations were lowered. Furthermore, social security and pensions were increased to provide a social base income. Ordoliberals have stated that these policies led to the {{lang|de|[[Wirtschaftswunder]]}}, or economic miracle.<ref>{{cite web |title=Ordoliberals |url=https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/commandingheights/shared/minitext/ess_ordoliberals.html |website=Commanding Heights: The Battle for the World Economy |publisher=[[PBS]] |date=2002 }}</ref>
==Theory== Ordoliberal theory holds that the [[state (polity)|state]] must create a proper legal environment for the economy and maintain a healthy level of [[competition policy|competition]] (rather than just "exchange") through measures that adhere to [[market (economics)|market principles]]. This is the foundation of its [[rational-legal authority|legitimacy]].<ref name="Megay">{{cite journal |last=Megay |first=Edward N. |year=1970 |title=Anti-Pluralist Liberalism: The German Neoliberals |journal=Political Science Quarterly |volume=85 |issue=3 |pages=422–42 |doi=10.2307/2147878 |jstor=2147878 }}<!--page 424: "Briefly, neoliberalism wants the government to establish and maintain the economic order, namely an open, free, and competitive market economy—but to leave the economic process to free private decisions within that economic order"--></ref> The concern is that, if the state does not take active measures to foster competition, [[corporation|firms]] with [[monopoly]] (or [[oligopoly]]) power will emerge, which will not only subvert the advantages offered by the [[market economy]], but also possibly undermine good government, since strong economic power can be transformed into political power.<ref>{{cite journal |first=Vatiero |last=Massimiliano |year=2010 |title=The Ordoliberal notion of market power: an institutionalist reassessment |journal=European Competition Journal |volume=6 |issue=3 |pages=689–707 |doi=10.5235/ecj.v6n3.689 }}</ref>
According to [[Stephen Padgett]] "A central tenet of ordo-liberalism is a clearly defined division of [[labour (economics)|labor]] in economic management, with specific responsibilities assigned to particular institutions. [[Monetary policy]] should be the responsibility of a [[central bank]] committed to monetary stability and low [[inflation]], and insulated from political pressure by independent status. [[Fiscal policy]]—balancing [[tax revenue]] against [[government expenditure]]—is the domain of the government, whilst [[macroeconomics|macro-economic]] policy is the preserve of [[employment#Employer|employers]] and [[trade unions]]."<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/?id=Bo-C2uExHw8C&pg=PA126&dq=A+central+tenet+of+ordo-liberalism+is+a+clearly+defined+division+of+labor+in+economic+management#v=onepage&q=A%20central%20tenet%20of%20ordo-liberalism%20is%20a%20clearly%20defined%20division%20of%20labor%20in%20economic%20management&f=false |first=Stephen |last=Padgett |chapter=Political Economy: The German Model under Stress |editor1-first=Stephen |editor1-last=Padgett |editor2-first=William E. |editor2-last=Paterson |editor3-first=Gordon |editor3-last=Smith |title=Developments in German Politics 3 |pages=126–27 |publisher=Duke University Press |year=2003 |isbn=978-0822332664 }}</ref> The state should form an economic order instead of directing economic processes, and three negative examples ordoliberals used to back their theories were [[Nazism]], [[Keynesianism]], and [[USSR|Russian socialism]].<ref>{{cite book |last=Foucault |first=Michel |title=The Birth of Biopolitics: Lectures at the College de France (1978–9) |translator-first=Graham |translator-last=Burchell |editor-first=Michael |editor-last=Senellart |edition=1st Picador Paperback |location=New York |publisher=Palgrave MacMillan |year=2010 |pages=107–10 |title-link=The Birth of Biopolitics }}</ref> The Ordoliberal idea of a social market economy is often seen as a [[progressivism|progressive]] alternative beyond [[left-wing politics|left]] and [[right-wing politics|right]]<ref>[http://www.esrc.ac.uk/my.../391448ec-84a9-42a5-bb79-4be1e721524a ]{{dead link|date=August 2013}}</ref> and as a [[third way (centrism)|third way]] between [[collectivism]] and [[classical liberalism|laissez-faire liberalism]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://docs.google.com/viewer?a=v&q=cache:r39x55yOrK4J:www.bisa.ac.uk/index.php%3Foption%3Dcom_bisa%26task%3Ddownload_paper%26no_html%3D1%26passed_paper_id%3D137+&hl=en&gl=uk&pid=bl&srcid=ADGEEShgu-KV-_z-Rd5F456Ye-SfRrehkgqTkt-sFcUWZtjtyowxWCEWOR83ae6Fa9XMXs3MrQjAoGEy6VbvjVSkw0hTxlhLtb7K7nSDezGPZqIoek6T09XH3y_488LnbVWxAiltEqt9&sig=AHIEtbSc3XM5GM5Ff1ZRPz7zT_w2StGrZA |title=Google Drive Viewer |publisher=Docs.google.com |date= |accessdate=2013-08-01}}</ref>
While the ordoliberal idea of a social market is similar to that of the [[third way (centrism)|third-way social democracy]] advocated by the likes of the [[New Labour]] government (especially during the [[premiership of Tony Blair]]), there are a few key differences. Whilst they both adhere to the idea of providing a moderate stance between [[socialism]] and [[capitalism]], the ordoliberal social market model often combines [[private enterprise]] with government [[regulation]] to establish fair [[competition (economics)|competition]] (although German network industries are known to have been deregulated),<ref name="ifw-kiel.de">{{citation |contribution=Germany’s Social Market Economy: How Sustainable is the Welfare State? |contribution-url=http://www.ifw-kiel.de/das-ifw/organisation/siebert/siebert-pdf/Washington2003.pdf |first=Horst |last=Siebert |authorlink=Horst Siebert |title=Paper presented at the American Institute for Contemporary German Studies, Johns Hopkins University |date=28 May 2003 |chapter-format=PDF |title-link=Johns Hopkins University }}</ref> whereas advocates of the third-way social democracy model have been known to oversee multiple economic [[deregulation]]s. The third way social democracy model has also foreseen a clash of ideas regarding the establishment of the [[welfare state]], in comparison to the ordoliberal's idea of a social market model being open to the [[economics|benefits]] of [[social welfare]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://wirtschaftslexikon.gabler.de/Definition/soziale-marktwirtschaft.html |title=Soziale Marktwirtschaft |website=Gabler Wirtschaftslexikon |language=de |date= |accessdate=2013-08-01}}</ref>
Ordoliberals are also known for pursuing a minimum [[configuration management|configuration of vital resources]] and [[progressive tax]]ation.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://toulouse-justice-2011.fr/fullpapers/b4woersdorfer.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-11-09 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131203004642/http://toulouse-justice-2011.fr/fullpapers/b4woersdorfer.pdf |archivedate=2013-12-03 }}</ref> The ordoliberal emphasis on the [[privatization]] of [[public services]] and other public firms such as [[telecommunication]] services;<ref name="ifw-kiel.de"/> [[redistribution of wealth|wealth redistribution]] and [[minimum wage]] laws as regulative principles makes clear the links between this economic model and the social market economy.<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/?id=e2UIjKCfRosC&pg=PA13 |title=Greening EU Competition Law and Policy |first=Suzanne |last=Kingston |publisher=[[Cambridge University Press]] |date=27 October 2011 |accessdate=1 August 2013 |isbn=9781139502788 }}</ref>
{{lang|de|[[Wilhelm Röpke]]|italic=no}} considered ordoliberalism to be "liberal conservatism", against [[capitalism]] in his work {{lang|la|Civitas Humana}} ("A Humane Order of Society", 1944). {{lang|de|[[Alexander Rüstow]]|italics=no}} also criticized [[laissez-faire]] [[capitalism]] in his work {{lang|de|Das Versagen des Wirtschaftsliberalismus|italic=yes}} ("The Failure of Economic Liberalism", 1950). The ordoliberals thus separated themselves from [[classical liberal]]s<ref name="Megay"/><ref>{{cite journal |last=Friedrich |first=Carl J. |year=1955|title=The Political Thought of Neo-Liberalism |journal=American Political Science Review |volume=49 |issue=2 |pages=509–25 |doi=10.2307/1951819 |jstor=1951819}}</ref> and valued the idea of [[social justice]].<ref>{{cite book |first=Walter |last=Oswalt |chapter=Zur Einführung: Walter Eucken (1891–1950) |editor1-first=Nils |editor1-last=Goldschmidt |editor2-first=Michael |editor2-last=Wohlgemuth |title=Grundtexte zur Freiburger Tradition der Ordnungsökonomik |isbn=978-3-16-148297-7 |page=128 |language=German|year=2008 }}</ref> "[[Social security]] and social justice", wrote {{lang|de|Eucken|italic=no}}, "are the greatest concerns of our time".<ref>{{Cite journal|author=OSO |title=Ordoliberalism: A New Intellectual Framework for Competition Law |publisher=Oxfordscholarship.com |date=1999-02-22 |doi=10.1093/acprof:oso/9780199244010.001.0001/acprof-9780199244010-chapter-7 |doi-broken-date=2018-08-26 }}</ref>
{{lang|fr|[[Michel Foucault]]|italic=no}} also notes the similarity (beyond just historical contemporaneity) between the Ordo/Freiburg school and the [[Frankfurt School]] of [[critical theory]], due to their inheritance from {{lang|de|[[Max Weber]]|italic=no}}. That is, both recognise the "[[rationalization (economics)|irrational rationality]]" of the capitalist system, but not the "[[dialectical materialism|logic of contradiction]]" that [[Karl Marx|Marx]] posited. Both groups took up the same problem, but in vastly different directions.<ref>[[Michel Foucault]], ''[[The Birth of Biopolitics]]'', 105.</ref> The political philosophy of Ordoliberals was influenced by [[Aristotle]], {{lang|fr|[[Alexis de Tocqueville|de Tocqueville]]|italic=no}}, {{lang|de|[[Georg Wilhelm Friedrich Hegel|Hegel]]|italic=no}}, {{lang|de|[[Oswald Spengler|Spengler]]|italic=no}}, {{lang|de|[[Karl Mannheim|Mannheim]]|italic=no}}, {{lang|de|Max Weber|italic=no}}, and {{lang|de|[[Edmund Husserl|Husserl]]|italic=no}}.<ref>Foucault, ''The Birth of Biopolitics'', 103–105.</ref>
==Criticism== {{Expand section|date=August 2018}} According to {{lang|de|Sebastian Dullien|italic=no}} and {{lang|de|[[Ulrike Guérot]]|italic=no}}, ordoliberalism is central to the German approach to the [[European sovereign-debt crisis]], which has often led to conflicts with other European countries.<ref>{{cite book |first1=Sebastian |last1=Dullien |first2=Ulrike |last2=Guérot |author-link2=Ulrike Guérot |title=The Long Shadow of Ordoliberalism: Germany's Approach to the Euro Crisis |url=http://www.ecfr.eu/page/-/ECFR49_GERMANY_BRIEF_AW.pdf |isbn=978-1-906538-49-1 |location=London |publisher=European Council on Foreign Relations |year=2012}}</ref>
Nobel laureate [[Friedrich Hayek]] commented on the Ordoliberals in his 1951 article, "The Transmission of the Ideals of Freedom".<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Hayek |first1=Friedrich A. |title=The Transmission of the Ideals of Freedom |journal=Econ Journal Watch |date=2012 |volume=9 |issue=2 |pages=163–69 |url=https://econjwatch.org/articles/the-transmission-of-the-ideals-of-economic-freedom?ref=articles }}</ref>
==See also== * [[Allocative efficiency]] * [[Freiburg School]] * [[Liberal conservatism]] * [[Radical centrism]] * [[Social market economy]]
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
==Further reading== * {{cite book |editor-first=Alan |editor-last=Peacock |editor2-first=Hans |editor2-last=Willgerodt |title=Germany's Social Market Economy: Origins and Evolution |location=London |publisher=Macmillan |year=1989 |isbn=978-0-333-48563-7 }} * {{cite book |editor-first=Christian |editor-last=Glossner |title=The Making of the German Post-war Economy: Political Communication and Public Reception of the Social Market Economy After World War Two |location=London |publisher=I.B.Tauris |year=1989 |isbn=978-1-780-76421-4 }} * {{cite journal |last1=Nedergaard |first1=Peter |last2=Snaith |first2=Holly |author-link1=Peter Nedergaard |title='As I drifted on a river I could not control': the unintended ordoliberal consequences of the Eurozone crisis |journal=[[Journal of Common Market Studies]] |volume=53 |issue=5 |pages=1094–09 |doi=10.1111/jcms.12249 |date=September 2015 }}

{{colorbox|#011053}} [[Dark blue (colour)|Dark blue]] |colorcode = #011053 |headquarters = [[Split, Croatia]]{{cite web|url=http://narodne-novine.nn.hr/clanci/sluzbeni/2015_09_96_1866.html |title=Statut političke stranke Pametno |publisher=[[Narodne novine]] |date=9 September 2015 |accessdate=6 April 2017}} |newspaper = |membership = 250 (2016){{cite web|author=Hanza Media |url=http://www.jutarnji.hr/globus/Globus-politika/predsjednica-stranke-pametno-zeljeli-bismo-da-jokic-bude-nas-kandidat-na-izborima/4505282/ |title=PREDSJEDNICA STRANKE PAMETNO 'Željeli bismo da Jokić bude naš kandidat na izborima' |publisher=[[Jutarnji list]] |date=7 July 2016 |accessdate=6 April 2017}} |seats1_title = [[Croatian Parliament|Sabor]] |seats1 = {{Composition bar|0|151|hex={{Smart (Political party)/meta/color}}}} |seats2_title = [[European Parliament]] |seats2 = {{Composition bar|0|11|hex={{Smart (Political party)/meta/color}}}} |seats3_title = [[Counties of Croatia|County Prefects]] |seats3 = {{Composition bar|0|21|hex={{Smart (Political party)/meta/color}}}} |seats4_title = [[Cities of Croatia|Mayors]] |seats4 = {{Composition bar|0|128|hex={{Smart (Political party)/meta/color}}}} |website = {{url|http://pametno.org}} }} '''Pametno''' ({{lang-en|Intelligently}}) is a [[liberalism|liberal]] [[List of political parties in Croatia|political party]] in [[Croatia]]. The party was formed in [[Split, Croatia|Split]] in 2015 out of the citizens' initiative ''Za pametne ljude i pametan grad'' ("For smart people and a smart city").{{cite web|url=http://radio.hrt.hr/radio-split/clanak/osnovana-stranka-pametno/94302/ |title=Osnovana stranka Pametno :: Radio Split |publisher=Radio.hrt.hr |date=14 June 2015 |accessdate=6 April 2017}} The fundamental values endorsed by the party are the promotion of democracy, accountable and transparent management of public resources, civil proactive protection of fundamental human rights, economic development and environmental protection.{{cite web|author=By admin |url=https://www.pametno.org/tko-smo-mi/o-nama/ |title=O nama |publisher=Pametno |date=21 September 2015 |accessdate=6 April 2017}} The Party's priorities are structural reforms, education and science,{{cite web|author=[[HINA|Hina]] |url=http://www.index.hr/vijesti/clanak/novoosnovana-stranka-pametno-predstavila-svoj-program/845782.aspx |title=Marijana Puljak predstavila stranku "Pametno": Treba ograničiti mandat političarima - Vijesti |publisher=[[Index.hr]] |date=3 October 2015 |accessdate=6 April 2017}} and it adheres to the values of "modern Western European countries". ==History== Pametno was founded in 2013 as citizens' initiative ''Za pametne ljude i pametan grad'' ("For smart people and a smart city") in the second most populous city in Croatia, [[Split, Croatia|Split]], by computer scientist Marijana Puljak. In 2010, Puljak served as President of the Split City District of Žnjan which had around 6000 citizens. During her tenure, she achieved success by reviving social life in the district, launching the construction of a children's playground and obtaining a building permit for a new district school. In 2013, she founded the citizens' initiative, competed in the [[Croatian local elections, 2013|2013 local elections]] and eventually, surprisingly, ended up winning 4 seats in the Split City Council. In 2015, the citizens' initiative was transformed into a political party whose work was based on the principles of 'New people for a new policy', 'Science and education as the foundation of society' and 'Policies based on evidence'. Pametno participated in the [[Croatian parliamentary election, 2015|2015 parliamentary election]] in the 10th [[Croatian Parliament electoral districts|electoral district]] but did not win any seats in the Parliament. In the [[Croatian parliamentary election, 2016|2016 extraordinary parliamentary election]], the Party went national as part of the two-party "Turn Croatia Around" coalition, eventually coming in 7th in term of votes won, but winning no seats in the Parliament. At the [[Croatian local elections, 2017|2017 local elections]], the Party nominated Marijana Puljak as its candidate for the position of the [[Mayor of Split]].{{cite web|author=Hina |url=http://www.jutarnji.hr/vijesti/hrvatska/marijana-puljak-kandidatkinja-stranke-pametno-za-splitsku-gradonacelnicu/5519611/ |title=Marijana Puljak kandidatkinja stranke Pametno za splitsku gradonačelnicu |publisher=Jutarnji list |date=17 January 2017 |accessdate=6 April 2017}} She eventually came in third and did not qualify for the second round. However, Pametno won 7 seats in the Split City Council; three more than the party had won at the previous election. On 1 December 2017 the party was admitted into the [[Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe Party]] as an affiliate member.https://www.aldeparty.eu/news/alde-welcomes-new-member-parties ==Electoral results== ===Parliament (''Sabor'')=== The following is a summary of the party's results in legislative elections for the [[Croatian Parliament]]. The "Votes won" and "Percentage" columns include sums of votes won by pre-election coalitions Pametno had been part of.
